column1: Vaginal bleeding during pregnancy is any discharge of blood from the vagina.
Some women have vaginal bleeding during their first 20 weeks of pregnancy.
Spotting can be a sign of a pregnancy where the fertilized egg develops outside the uterus (ectopic pregnancy).

It may be caused by: - Having sex - An infection - The fertilized egg implanting in the uterus - Hormone changes - Other factors that will not harm the woman or baby More serious causes of first-trimester bleeding include: - A miscarriage, which is the loss of the pregnancy before the embryo or fetus can live on its own outside the uterus.
Almost all women who miscarry will have bleeding before a miscarriage.
- A molar pregnancy, in which a fertilized egg implants in the uterus that will not come to term.
If it is Rh negative, you will need treatment with a medicine called Rho(D) immune globulin to prevent complications with future pregnancies.
